question.text: Which of the following statements, about the advantage of roasting of sulphide ore before reduction is not true?

options.text: the magnitude of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></msubsup></math> of the sulphide is greater than those for <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> and <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math>

the  <math><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></msubsup></math>  is negative for roasting of sulphide ore to oxide
roasting of the sulphide to the oxide is thermodynamically feasible
carbon and hydrogen are suitable reducing agents for metal sulphides

solution.text: The standard free energies of formation  <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mfenced></math>  of most of the sulphides are greater than those of  <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>  and  <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> . Hence, neither carbon nor hydrogen can reduce metal sulphides to metal. The standard free energies of formation of oxides are much lower than those of  <math><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> . Therefore, oxidation of metal sulphides to metal oxides is thermodynamically favourable. Hence sulphide ore is roasted to the oxide before reduction.
